{{vgy|2004}}
'''Wii'''
{{vgrelease|JP|October 23, 2007}}{{vgrelease|NA|November 20, 2007}}{{vgrelease|EU|January 18, 2008}}{{vgrelease|AUS|January 24, 2008}} |genre= [[Shoot 'em up#Tube and rail shooters|Rail shooter]] |modes=[[Single player]], [[Multiplayer game|Multiplayer]] |cabinet=[[Video game arcade cabinet|Deluxe Cabinet]] |arcade system=[[Sega Chihiro]]{{cite web|title=Ghost Squad|url=http://www.arcade-museum.com/game_detail.php?game_id=13248|work=KLOV.com|publisher=The International Arcade Museum|accessdate=18 June 2011}} |sound=Amplified Stereo with Subwoofer (three channel) |display=[[Raster graphics|Raster]] }} {{Infobox video game |title=Ghost Squad Evolution |developer=[[Sega AM2]] |publisher=[[Sega]] |platforms=Arcade |released={{vgy|2007}} |genre=[[Shoot 'em up#Tube and rail shooters|Rail shooter]]{{cite web|title=Ghost Squad Evolution Deluxe: Ghost Squad has evolved! |url=http://www.segaarcade.com/node/289 |publisher=Sega Amusements USA Limited |accessdate=12 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721094822/http://www.segaarcade.com/node/289 |archivedate=21 July 2011 |df= }} |modes=[[Single player]], [[Multiplayer game|Multiplayer]] |cabinet=[[Video game arcade cabinet|Deluxe Cabinet]] |arcade system=[[Sega Lindbergh]]{{cite book|title=Ghost Squad Evolution Owners Manual|publisher=Sega Amusements USA Limited|url=http://www.segaarcade.us.com/__assets__/GamePDFs/Games/00037/ghost-squad-evolution-manual.pdf}} |display=[[Projection screen|Toshiba 50” Projection]]
29" Standard Edition }} '''''Ghost Squad''''' and '''''Ghost Squad: Evolution''''' are [[light gun]] [[Shoot 'em up#Tube and rail shooters|rail shooter]] [[arcade game]]s developed and published by Sega. A home version of the original ''Ghost Squad'' was developed for [[Nintendo]]'s [[Wii]] [[video game console|game console]].{{cite web|title=GameSpot: Ghost Squad (Wii)|url=http://www.gamespot.com/wii/action/ghostsquad/index.html?tag=result%3Btitle%3B4|publisher=CBS Interactive Inc.|accessdate=18 June 2011}} A sequel, ''Operation GHOST'', was released in arcades in 2012. ==''Ghost Squad'' (Arcade)== Sega released ''Ghost Squad'' for the arcade in 2004. ''Ghost Squad'' features a simulated IR light gun shaped similar to the standard issue weapon the game's protagonists use. This light gun is intended to function realistically: it features a working [[Selective fire|fire selector switch]], a stock, force-feedback recoil, and [[iron sights]]. To ensure that the light gun fires accurately, a 20-second "calibration" mode is provided in which the game adjusts for any jostling or damage to the rifle's light-emitting components. ''Ghost Squad'' features different weapons, each with its firing and reload properties (i.e. long shot splash, long reload time) which affect its difficulty of use. ''Ghost Squad'' features three semi non-linear levels with adjustable difficulty and branching choices, ranging from the jungle, a government-restricted villa, and inside an [[Air Force One]] flight. There are many sub-activities in the game, such as defusing bombs and throwing grenades to disable armor, which are accomplished via the secondary "Action" trigger on the gun's [[foregrip]]. ===Arcade version data features=== The arcade version of ''Ghost Squad'' use "IC Cards" to save the players customized character data, score, and provide the player with experience points, new outfits, new weapons, and increased rank. The card is available for players to purchase at some arcades. The card allows the player a maximum of 100 game and sixteen levels of difficulty. After 100 games the card must be recharged by purchasing a new card. The game also utilizes an internet ranking system, that is accessed when using a password provided by the game. Most ''Ghost Squad'' cabinets in the United States do not have card slots. However, players have immediate access to four costumes, four guns, and the first four mission levels. ==''Ghost Squad: Evolution'' (arcade)== ''Ghost Squad Evolution'' is the arcade followup to the original ''Ghost Squad''. It was developed and published by Sega and released in 2007. In ''Ghost Squad: Evolution'' the player is a member of Alpha Unit, or members of the “Ghost Squad”, an unofficial unit of the anti-terrorist group, Multi-Operation-Program (M.O.P.). [[Non-player character|Non-playable characters]] include fellow M.O.P. members consisting of the Commander, who provides radio backup and pertinent advice to the player. Along with the Bravo and Charlie Unit who assist the player in suppressing the terrorist threat. The rifle can be set from single shot, to 3 burst shot to automatic fire. As well as a special effects to suit the situation Night Vision, Flash Light for the mounted gun, and scope for sniper rifle. The gun also features an action button which is used to pull off special moves like hand-to-hand combat. As well as recoil effects on every shot fired.{{cite web|title=Ghost Squad Evolution - Ghost Squad 2|url=http://www.highwaygames.com/products/view.php?id=3267|publisher=Highway Games|accessdate=18 June 2011}} Each mission contains multiple routes for the player to choose. Special events occur throughout the game depending on the route chosen, such as securing hostages, bomb removal, or providing friendly cover fire. The game is broken into 3 missions with 16 total levels. All 16 can be selected from the beginning. There are 14 costumes available for character customization, however, the costumes have no effect on gameplay. There are 25 different weapons. ==''Ghost Squad'' (Wii)== Sega published the Polygon Magic developed Wii port of ''Ghost Squad'' in Japan on October 25, 2007, and in the U.S. on November 20, 2007. It uses the [[Wii Zapper]] as a multi-purpose tool to allow players easy control of targeting enemies, defusing bombs, and detaining hostages. ''Ghost Squad'' takes advantage of the [[Wii Remote]]'s pointer functionality, the nunchuk, and the Wii Zapper giving players controller flexibility. In addition, the game features a pointer calibration mode, enabling players to use line-of-sight aiming and fire precisely where the Wii Remote is pointed. The player has the option to turn off the on-screen pointer for more points. Exclusive to the [[Wii]] conversion of the game are four-player support, and an online [[Score (game)#High score|high score]] leaderboard via the [[Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection]].{{cite web|last=Casamassina|first=Matt|title=SEGA Announces Ghost Squad for Wii|url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/787/787072p1.html |publisher=IGN Entertainment|accessdate=18 June 2011}} ==Reception== ''Ghost Squad'' for the Wii received a metascore of 69 on [[Metacritic]].{{cite web|title=Metacritic: Ghost Squad (Wii)|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/wii/ghost-squad|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=18 June 2011}} IGN gave it a 7.5, remarking that "most of what made ''Ghost Squad'' fun in the arcades is still retained though, as there's a huge emphasis on weapon management and mid-level missions".{{cite web|last=Bozon|title=Ghost Squad Review|url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/836/836873p1.html|publisher=IGN Entertainment|accessdate=18 June 2011}} ==See also== *''[[The House of the Dead 2 & 3 Return]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.sega-ghostsquad.com/}} (available in Japanese or English) {{DEFAULTSORT:Ghost Squad (Arcade Game)}} [[Category:2007 video games]] [[Category:Arcade games]] [[Category:Light gun games]] [[Category:Polygon Magic games]] [[Category:Rail shooters]] [[Category:Sega-AM2 games]] [[Category:Sega arcade games]] [[Category:Terrorism in fiction]] [[Category:Wii Zapper games]] [[Category:Wii Wi-Fi games]] [[Category:Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection games]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]]

revision.comment: this is an update to the Golden generation of HAndball players
revision.text:
{{Original research|date=June 2012}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2011}} In [[sport]], a '''golden generation''' or '''golden team''' is an exceptionally gifted group of players of similar age, whose achievements reach or are expected to reach a level of success beyond that which their team had previously achieved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/513450/20131013/england-steven-gerrard-frank-lampard-figo-denis.htm |title=Curse of the Golden Generations: The Unrewarded Exploits of Bergkamp, Figo, Drogba and England - International Business Times UK |publisher=Ibtimes.co.uk |date=2013-10-13 |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/team/belgium/459/blog/post/1923296/belgium-golden-generation|title=Belgium Golden Generation - ESPN FC|work=ESPNFC.com|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref> Below is a list of teams who have been referred to by the media as golden generations, most of which played in the 21st century.
==Origins== It was first coined by the Portuguese sports media to refer to a group of exceptionally gifted teenage Portuguese footballers. This group of players, spearheaded by "Golden Boy" [[Luís Figo]], won two [[FIFA U-20 World Cup|Football World Youth Championship]]s in [[1989 FIFA World Youth Championship|1989]] and [[1991 FIFA World Youth Championship|1991]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/worldcup2002/hi/team_pages/portugal/newsid_1985000/1985619.stm|title= Portugal must take their chance|accessdate= |work= BBC|publisher= |date= May 13, 2002}}</ref> This group were close to retirement in the early part of the 21st century, leading the European sports media to spotlight the Golden Generation's chances of winning a senior trophy at tournaments such as [[UEFA Euro 2000]], the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]], [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]] (which Portugal hosted) and the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]].
Since then, it has been used by media in many different countries, with usage spreading to other areas, for example, in [[rugby union|rugby]].
==Basketball==
===Argentina (2000–2012)=== By winning the [[gold medal]] in the [[Americas Championship 2001]], [[silver medal]] in [[2002 FIBA World Championship]], the gold medal in [[Basketball at the 2004 Summer Olympics]], gold medal in [[FIBA Diamond Ball]] 2008, [[bronze medal]] in [[Basketball at the 2008 Summer Olympics]], and gold medal in [[2011 FIBA Americas Championship]] played in the city of [[Mar del Plata]], [[Argentina]]. Resulting in Argentina reached the first position in the [[FIBA World Rankings|FIBA Men's Ranking]] at the end of the [[2008 Olympic Games]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://aol.sportingnews.com/nba/story/2011-08-30/star-studded-but-aging-argentine-squad-looks-to-add-to-achievements-with-fiba-am|title= Star-studded but aging Argentine squad looks to add to achievements with FIBA Americas gold|accessdate= |work= |publisher=sportingnews |date= 12 September 2011}}</ref>
=== Spain (2006–present) === {{expand section|date=August 2018}}
==Football== === Asia === ==== Australia (2006–2014) ==== This Australian team waited 32 years to qualify for a FIFA World Cup tournament. This group of players formed the backbone of Australia's [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], [[2007 AFC Asian Cup]], [[2010 FIFA World Cup]], and [[2011 AFC Asian Cup]] squads and was used extensively during Australia's qualification matches for those respective tournaments, with this crop of players considered to be among the best Australia have ever produced. The Golden Generation is believed to have ended during the reign of [[Ange Postecoglou]] as manager of Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theroar.com.au/2013/10/18/its-time-for-australia-to-move-on-from-the-golden-generation/|title=It’s time for Australia to move on from the ‘Golden Generation’|date=October 18, 2013|work=The Roar|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/football/asian-cup/fox-sports-simon-hill-says-the-asian-cup-final-will-be-fitting-farewell-to-socceroos-golden-generation/story-e6frf4fu-1225995483593?nk=940d0841d9989dd332a822175486d00d |archive-url=https://archive.is/20141203111942/http://www.foxsports.com.au/football/asian-cup/fox-sports-simon-hill-says-the-asian-cup-final-will-be-fitting-farewell-to-socceroos-golden-generation/story-e6frf4fu-1225995483593?nk=940d0841d9989dd332a822175486d00d |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-12-03 |title=Asian Cup 2015 |publisher=Foxsports.com.au |accessdate=2015-06-19 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/jun/06/the-socceroos-golden-generation-world-cup|title=The Socceroos' golden generation: extraordinary in their ordinariness|author=Aaron Timms|work=the Guardian|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/soccer/socceroos-golden-generation-fall-one-by-one-to-the-sniper-20140326-zqnd8.html|title=Socceroos' Golden Generation fall one by one to the sniper|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Craig Foster |url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/soccer/socceroos-golden-generation-has-much-to-teach-our-youth-20120721-22gti.html |title=Socceroos' golden generation has much to teach our youth |publisher=Smh.com.au |date= |accessdate=2015-06-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/soccer/asian-cup-2015-after-historic-triumph-socceroos-now-target-world-cup-20150201-1334zz.html|title=Asian Cup 2015: After historic triumph, Socceroos now target World Cup|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref>
=== Europe === ==== Belgium (2013–) ==== [[File:Belgium national football team World Cup 2018.jpg|alt=|thumb|Belgium's "[[2018 FIFA World Cup squads#Belgium|Golden Generation]]" won the bronze medal at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]; after beating [[England national football team|England]] 2–0.]] The current Belgium squad is considered by the media, press and fans as the best Belgium squad ever; featuring key players such as Kevin De Bruyne, Eden Hazard, Romelu Lukaku, Axel Witsel, Thibaut Courtois, Toby Alderweireld and Jan Vertonghen.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12098/11387201/belgium-are-much-more-than-a-golden-generation-and-it-is-not-luck|title=Belgium are much more than a golden generation and it is not luck|work=Sky Sports|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/27827569|title=World Cup 2014: How Belgium built their golden generation|date=2014-06-16|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44747340|title=World Cup 2018: Are Belgium now favourites to win after beating Brazil?|date=2018-07-06|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jun/10/belgium-world-cup-2018-team-guide-tactics-key-players-and-expert-predictions|title=Belgium World Cup 2018 team guide: tactics, key players and expert predictions|last=Terreur|first=Kristof|date=2018-06-10|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-07-16}}</ref> At the 2018 FIFA World Cup, from the beginning of the tournament, Belgium were considered by many as one of the favourites to win the tournament.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-5137385/Belgium-travel-World-Cup-Russia-sixth-favourites.html|title=Belgium travel to World Cup in Russia as sixth favourites|work=Mail Online|access-date=2018-07-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/who-will-win-world-cup-2018-the-favourites-outsiders/1447p3mxem6v13dm0yk4jwwbu|title=Who will win World Cup 2018? The favourites, outsiders, underdogs & latest odds {{!}} Goal.com|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbssports.com/soccer/world-cup/news/world-cup-2018-odds-brazil-the-favorite-followed-by-germany-spain-and-france/|title=World Cup 2018 odds: Brazil the favorite, followed by Germany, Spain and France|work=CBSSports.com|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en}}</ref> Belgium finished top of the group on maximum points, beating Panama, Tunisia and England.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/groups/|title=2018 FIFA World Cup Russia™ - FIFA.com|last=FIFA.com|website=www.fifa.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-07-16}}</ref> Belgium earned a famous 2–1 win over five-time champions Brazil in the quarter-finals.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44652178|title=World Cup 2018: Belgium produce masterclass to knock out Brazil with 2-1 win|date=2018-07-06|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> Belgium lost 1–0 to France in the semi-finals<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/worldcup/france-10-belgium-samuel-umtiti-sends-les-bleus-into-world-cup-final-a3884181.html|title=France 1-0 Belgium: Umtiti sends Les Bleus into World Cup final|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref>, but beat England in the third place play-off, Belgium's best ever result at the World Cup and best result at a major tournament since 1980.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44748604|title=World Cup 2018: England finish fourth after Belgium defeat|date=2018-07-14|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==== Bosnia and Herzegovina (2010–) ==== The current [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina national team]] was seen by many as the most talented generation the nation has ever had.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://sportsport.ba/bh_fudbal/fifa-bih-je-konacno-docekala-svoju-zlatnu-generaciju/106992 |title=FIFA: BiH je konačno dočekala svoju zlatnu generaciju |publisher=SportSport.ba |date=2013-06-13 |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldranking/news/newsid=2107855/index.html |title=Best-ever Bosnia scale new heights |publisher=FIFA.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/10377174/Bosnias-golden-generation-on-verge-of-bringing-World-Cup-football-to-war-ravaged-nation.html |title=Bosnia's golden generation on verge of bringing World Cup football to war-ravaged nation |publisher=Telegraph |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> They qualified for [[2014 FIFA World Cup]], their first ever World Cup since their independence and got their first ever victory against [[Iran national football team|Iran]] on 25 June 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/25285298|title=World Cup: Bosnia-Hercegovina 3-1 Iran|date=2014-06-25|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==== Croatia (2008–2018) ==== [[File:Croatia's post-match huddle after the 2018 FIFA World Cup Final.jpg|thumb|Croatia players pose with [[Vladimir Putin]] and [[Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović]] after the [[2018 FIFA World Cup Final]].]]
The [[Croatia national football team#Current squad|current Croatia team]] have been considered by several [[United Kingdom|British]] media such as ''[[The Guardian]]'' as the "[[Croatia national football team#Dalić period and the second "golden generation" (2017–present)|Second Coming of the Golden Generation]]";<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jun/16/croatia-luka-modric-great-expectations|title=Croatia’s Luka Modric: ‘It is only right there are great expectations of us’|last=Walker|first=Shaun|date=2018-06-16|website=The Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-07-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/football/world-cup-2018-will-croatia-s-new-golden-generation-beat-les-bleus-in-the-final|title=World Cup 2018: Will Croatia’s new golden generation beat Les Bleus in the final?|date=2018-07-13|access-date=2018-07-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.besoccer.com/new/the-time-is-now-for-croatia-s-second-golden-generation-458062|title=The time is now for Croatia's second golden generation|work=BeSoccer|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-EN}}</ref> in reference to the [[Croatia national football team#Blažević period and the "golden generation" (1994–99)|Golden Generation]] of Croatia from the late 1990s who won the bronze medal in at the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]], Croatia's debut at the World Cup.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://scroll.in/field/886326/suker-prosinecki-boban-croatias-first-golden-generation-that-lit-up-england-96-and-france-98|title=Suker, Prosinecki, Boban: Croatia’s first ‘Golden Generation’ that lit up England ‘96 and France ‘98|last=Bhattacharya|first=Arka|work=Scroll.in|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blog.betvictor.com/en-gb/sports/international-football/russia-2018/croatia-potential-world-cup/|title=Can Croatia's Second Golden Generation in 20 Years Fulfil Their Potential?|date=2018-06-06|work=BetVictor Blog|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> The team, under the leadership of captain [[Luka Modrić]] and the style of play by key players such as [[Mario Mandžukić]], [[Ivan Rakitić]] and [[Ivan Perišić]], reached the [[2018 FIFA World Cup Final|2018 FIFA World Cup final]], losing to [[France national football team|France]] 2–4, thus earning the silver medal. From the final onwards, however, their results continued to decline following the retirement of Mandžukić, Danijel Subasic and Vedran Corluka, and they debuted at the UEFA Nations League with a 6-0 loss to Spain in Elche. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/iceland-vs-croatia-world-cup-2018-ivan-rakitic-luka-modric-midfield-tactics-preview-partnership-a8416581.html|title=Are Ivan Rakitic and Luka Modric the World Cup's biggest unsung heroes?|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/modric-makes-the-world-cup-look-easy-kaka-praises-croatia/dfv4zkrswsr11qdn55m0e45yk|title=World Cup Final: 'Modric makes the World Cup look easy' - Kaka praises Croatia captain {{!}} Goal.com|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/jul/15/world-cup-2018-final-france-v-croatia-live|title=World Cup 2018 final: France 4-2 Croatia – as it happened|last=commentary)|first=Barry Glendenning (match|date=2018-07-15|work=The Guardian|access-date=2018-07-16|last2=(build-up)|first2=Will Unwin|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|last3=McVeigh|first3=Niall}}</ref> The squad were praised for their performance at the World Cup.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxsportsasia.com/football/world-cup/912215/croatia-unheralded-football-powers/|title=Croatia: Unheralded powers of football and their Golden Generation|date=2018-07-13|work=FOX Sports Asia|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44754965|title=World Cup 2018: France beat Croatia 4-2 in World Cup final|date=2018-07-15|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==== Czech Republic (1996–2006) ==== The Golden generation of the [[Czech Republic]] were born in the late seventies and early eighties of the twentieth century. Highlights of their generation include finishing second in [[UEFA Euro 1996]]<ref>{{Citation|title=UEFA Euro 1996|date=2018-06-14|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=UEFA_Euro_1996&oldid=845841427|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-06-20}}</ref> and third in [[UEFA Euro 2004]].<ref>{{Citation|title=UEFA Euro 2004|date=2018-06-17|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=UEFA_Euro_2004&oldid=846257921|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-06-20}}</ref> The [[Czech Republic national football team|national team]] was also qualified for the first time to a Fifa World Cup in [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006]]. During the first few years of the twenty first century the team were often ranked in the top five of the [[FIFA World Rankings|FIFA World Ranking]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.fifaranking.net/ranking/?d=2000-08-09|title=FIFA World Ranking as of Aug 2000 {{!}} FIFARANKING.net|website=en.fifaranking.net|language=en|access-date=2018-06-20}}</ref> [[Czech Republic]] was the second best team in the world in 2005.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.fifaranking.net/ranking/?d=2005-12-16|title=FIFA World Ranking as of Dec 2005 {{!}} FIFARANKING.net|website=en.fifaranking.net|language=en|access-date=2018-06-20}}</ref> Many of the squad during this time played in the best leagues in Europe for the likes of [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], [[Borussia Dortmund]], [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus F.C]]. One of them, [[Pavel Nedvěd]], even won the [[Ballon d'Or]] in 2003.<ref>{{Citation|title=Ballon d'Or|date=2018-05-24|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ballon_d%27Or&oldid=842827640|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-06-20}}</ref> For the first time in the history of this small Central European country a Czech player won the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]]. It happened in [[2005 UEFA Champions League Final|2005]] during ''Miracle of Istanbul.'' [[Milan Baroš]] and [[Vladimír Šmicer]] winning with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool FC]].
==== England (2001–2010, 2018–) ==== During the reign of [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]], [[Adam Crozier]], the chief executive of [[the Football Association]] and some members of the British media, touted players such as [[David Beckham]], [[Michael Owen]] and [[Steven Gerrard]] as the nucleus of a potential Golden Generation team. Despite some impressive performances such as the [[2001 Germany vs England football match]] in the 2002 World Cup qualifiers and the individual players' successes at club level, inconsistency resulted in this group of players failing to live up to expectations, resulting in the group becoming synonymous with disappointment and failed potential.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/Columnists/Column/0,,1852626,00.html | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=McClaren ends the golden era | date=August 18, 2006 | first=Kevin | last=McCarra}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/worldcup2006/comment/story/0,,1816198,00.html | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=England's golden generation are just big heads | date=July 9, 2006 | first=Paul | last=Wilson}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2006/teams/england/5137638.stm | work=BBC News | title=End of road for wayward England | date=July 2, 2006 | first=Phil | last=McNulty}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/internationals/article1826303.ece |location=London |work=The Independent |title=Eco Chic: All ethically made over |date=November 23, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061106081248/http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/internationals/article1826303.ece |archivedate=November 6, 2006 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= England, Beckham booted from Euro 2008|work= [[MSNBC]]|date=|url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21920060/|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/sam-wallace-golden-generation-fell-short-of-the-highest-standards-ndash-but-england-will-miss-them-2345567.html | title=Sam Wallace: 'Golden generation' fell short of the highest standards – but England will miss them |location=London | work=The Independent | first=Sam | last=Wallace | date=August 29, 2011}}</ref>
After Eriksson left in 2006 and [[Steve McClaren]] became manager, although many of the players continued to achieve success with their respective clubs, the team failed to qualify for [[UEFA Euro 2008]], only the second time England failed to qualify for a major tournament in over 20 years (of the last 12 major tournaments). [[Rio Ferdinand]] claimed that the pressure of the "Golden Generation" tag had a negative effect on the players, restricting their ability to perform to their full potential for the national team.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/may/10/rio-ferdinand-england-world-cup|title=Rio Ferdinand urges England's young Lions to be fearless at World Cup|author=Owen Gibson|work=the Guardian|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref> In 2017, [[Pep Guardiola]] said he could not understand why England did not achieve more with players such as Lampard, Carrick, Scholes, Gerrard, Terry and Ferdinand and claimed they were on the same level as Spain's golden generation of 2008–2014, The team entered a second golden generation in 2018, reaching the semi-finals of the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] and the Finals of the [[UEFA Nations League]], causing a resurgence of england fans and high expectations.<ref>{{cite web |last1=harshit |first1=raghav |title=Another golden generation in the making for England |url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/football/opinion-another-golden-generation-in-the-making-for-england |website=sportskeeda |publisher=sportskeeda |accessdate=19 November 2018}}</ref>
==== France (1998–2006) ==== In late 1998 the [[France national football team]] began a period of international dominance defeating [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] 3–0 to win the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]], becoming the first French team to win the [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]]. Two years later, [[David Trezeguet]]'s golden goal in extra time gave France a 2–1 win over [[Italy national football team|Italy]] to give France the [[UEFA Euro 2000|2000 European Championship]]. France were subsequently ranked No. 1 in the [[FIFA World Rankings]] and ranked No. 1 in the [[World Football Elo Ratings]] for two years. The team also secured the [[2001 FIFA Confederations Cup]]. Despite this impressive recent record the French team flopped at the [[2002 FIFA World Cup]], losing to newcomers Senegal in the opening match of the tournament and crashing out in the group stages without scoring a goal and taking only one point from their three games. A years later they were successful at the [[2003 FIFA Confederations Cup]]. They also reached the World Cup final in Berlin at the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], where they lost to Italy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=368242&root=worldcup&&cc=3436 |title=Finals bow for Zidane et al - ESPN FC |publisher=Soccernet.espn.go.com |date=2006-05-17 |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/english-players-are-an-endangered-species-we-must-do-more-to-protect-460942.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Sam | last=Wallace | title=English players are an endangered species we must do more to protect | date=August 10, 2007}}</ref> The French golden team<ref>{{cite news|url=https://sports.ndtv.com/football/blanc-under-pressure-amid-race-row-storm-1571506|title=Blanc under pressure amid race row storm|last=Grelard|first=Philippe|date=6 May 2011|publisher=[[NDTV]] Sports|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> was composed of the following players:
==== Hungary (1950–1956) ==== {{Main article|Golden Team}} Between 1950 and 1956, the team recorded 42 victories, 7 draws and just one defeat, in the [[1954 World Cup final]] against [[West Germany national football team|West Germany]]. Under the [[Elo rating system]] they achieved the highest rating recorded by a national side (2230 points, 30 June 1954).
==== Portugal (1994–2006) ==== Many of these players made up the youth national teams of Portugal that won consecutive FIFA Youth Championships in [[1989 FIFA World Youth Championship|1989]] and [[1991 FIFA World Youth Championship|1991]]. These teams were the step-up to the senior team. As a result, Portugal reached the semi-finals of [[2000 UEFA European Football Championship]] and were runners-up [[2004 UEFA European Football Championship|four years later]], on home soil. They were also [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] semi-finalists after a dominating run, though only [[Luís Figo]] was picked in the squad for the final tournament.<ref>{{cite news|title= 'Golden Generation' Must First Beat World Champion France : Can Portugal Go the Full Distance?|work= [[The New York Times]]|date=June 28, 2000|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/28/sports/28iht-soccer.2.t_21.html|accessdate=|first=Rob|last=Hughes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/soccer/world/2000/euro2000/news/2000/06/02/por_mainfeature_ap/ | work=CNN | title=Figo and Co. aim to fulfill Portugal's promise at Euros}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/soccer/07/04/port.rdp/ | work=CNN | title=SI.com - Soccer - Portugal's golden generation just misses glory - 4 July 2004 | date=July 4, 2004}}</ref> Some critics contend that many of the players underachieved at international level.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=373269&root=worldcup&&cc=5739|title= Portugal vs. France preview|accessdate= |work= ESPN|publisher= |date= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/euro2000/teams/portugal/808269.stm|title= Golden boys ready to shine|accessdate= |work= BBC|publisher= |date= June 27, 2000}}</ref>
==== Spain (2008–2014) ==== {{expand section|date=August 2018}} This generation of Spanish players helped [[Spain national football team|Spain]] win three titles: the [[UEFA European Championship]] in [[UEFA Euro 2008|2008]] and [[UEFA Euro 2012|2012]] and the [[FIFA World Cup]] in [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010]], while also reaching the final of the [[2013 FIFA Confederations Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/football/the-rise-and-fall-of-spains-golden-generation|title=The rise and fall of Spain’s golden generation|publisher=Sportskeeda|first=Mahir|last=Tajwar|date=4 July 2016|access-date=17 August 2018}}</ref> During this time, Spain also dominated the FIFA World Rankings until 2013, having first led the rankings in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/fifa-world-ranking/associations/association=esp/men/index.html|title=FIFA/Coca-Cola World Ranking: Spain|publisher=FIFA|access-date=17 August 2018}}</ref>
==== Yugoslavia (1987–1992) ==== Yugoslavia's generation of young footballers won the [[1987 FIFA World Youth Championship]] and finished runner-up at the [[1990 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]]. The nation then reached the quarter-finals of the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]] and, a year later, a [[Red Star Belgrade]] team featuring many of the [[Yugoslavia national football team|national team]]'s stars became the first Yugoslav side to ever win the [[1990–91 European Cup|European Cup]]. Yugoslavia qualified for [[UEFA Euro 1992]] with seven wins from eight matches and the best goalscoring record and goal difference of any team during the [[UEFA Euro 1992 qualifying|qualifying phase]]. However, the team was disqualified prior to the tournament due to the [[Yugoslav Wars]] (it was replaced by the eventual champion, [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]]) and did not play together again after the [[Breakup of Yugoslavia|country's division]]. Several players from the Yugoslav team went on to finish in third place at the [[1998 FIFA World Cup|1998 World Cup]] with [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2010/soccer/world-cup-2010/writers/jonathan_wilson/07/01/yugoslavia.1990/|title=Osim recalls what might have been for a brilliant Yugoslavia in 1990|date=1 July 2010|accessdate=18 June 2014|work=Sports Illustrated}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/england/2953134.stm|title=Serbia & Montenegro's new dawn|date=31 May 2003|accessdate=18 June 2014|work=BBC}}</ref>
===Africa=== ==== Algeria (2014–) ==== The [[Algeria national football team|Algerian team]] which reached the second round of the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] has been described as a golden generation, or a "second golden generation" in reference to the Algerian team which reached the [[1982 FIFA World Cup|1982]] and [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986]] World Cups and which won the [[1990 African Nations Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2014/m=7/news=lacen-this-golden-generation-has-matured-2393065.html|title=Lacen: This golden generation has matured|first=|last=FIFA.com|date=January 1, 1900|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://trueafrica.co/article/algerias-fennec-foxes-team-look-2017-african-cup-nations/|title=Is it Algeria's time to shine in the football world? - TRUE Africa|date=March 30, 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2015/1/15/7517161/algeria-africa-cup-of-nations-2015|title=After their World Cup heroics, all eyes will be on Algeria at AFCON.|publisher=}}</ref>
==== Ivory Coast (2006–2015) ==== Despite winning the 1992 edition of the [[Africa Cup of Nations]], the country saw an outpour of talent during the first half of the 2000s (decade). The majority of this generation consisted of talented players who enjoyed and still enjoy considerable success in Europe. Led by [[Didier Drogba]] (who is also the national team's highest ever goalscorer), several other players found contracts in the biggest football stages in the world. During this period, [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]] managed its first [[FIFA World Cup]] appearances in [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006]] and [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010]] respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/soccer/ivory-coast-les-elephants-world-cup-2014-barzil-didier-drogba-yaya-toure/|title=Last hurrah for Ivory Coast’s Golden Generation|date=26 May 2014|accessdate=29 May 2014|work=Sportsnet}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/ivory-coast/10589548/World-Cup-2014-Time-for-Ivory-Coasts-ageing-golden-generation-to-finally-make-an-impact-on-the-world-stage.html|title=World Cup 2014: Time for Ivory Coast's ageing golden generation to finally make an impact on the world stage|date=22 January 2014|accessdate=29 May 2014|work=The Telegraph}}</ref>. They also won the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations|Africa Cup of Nations]] in 2015.
=== South America === ==== Chile (2007–2017) ==== The Chile team won back to back Copa América titles in [[2015 Copa América|2015]] and in [[Copa América Centenario|2016]]. The backbone of this team came from the U-20 squad that went on to finish third in the [[2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup]]. However, in 2017 they inexplicably failed to qualify for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]], despite most of the squad being in the primes of their careers, following unexpected losses to [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia]] and [[Paraguay national football team|Paraguay]] in [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|qualification]].<ref>http://remezcla.com/sports/chile-golden-generation-world-cup/</ref>
==== Colombia (2012–) ==== The current Colombia team are considered as the "[[Colombia national football team#A new golden generation (2010–present)|Second Golden Generation]]" of Colombia, in reference to Colombia's [[Colombia national football team#1990s: Golden Era|Golden Generation]] from the 1980s and 1990s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/sport/brazil2014/2014/06/colombia-new-generation-born-2014613212422678440.html|title=Colombia's new generation is born|last=Rhys|first=Paul|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-07-16}}</ref> Under key players [[James Rodríguez]], [[Juan Cuadrado]] and [[Radamel Falcao]], the team reached the [[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage]] after topping a [[2014 FIFA World Cup Group C|group]] featuring [[Greece national football team|Greece]], [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]] and [[Japan national football team|Japan]], winning all three games.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/25285057|title=World Cup: Colombia 3-0 Greece|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/25285169|title=World Cup: Colombia 2-1 Ivory Coast|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/25455848|title=World Cup: Japan 1-4 Colombia|date=2014-06-24|work=BBC before suffering a 1–2 defeat to host nation [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]], in the [[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Brazil vs Colombia|quarter-finals]].<ref>{{Cite FIFA World Cup awards#Golden Boot|top goalscorer]]; and Colombia earned the [[2014 FIFA World Cup awards#FIFA Fair Play Trophy|FIFA Fair Play Award]].<ref>{{Cite men's national soccer team|United States]] 1–0.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2016/jun/25/usa-v-colombia-copa-america-live|title=USA 0-1 Colombia: Copa América – as it for [[2018 FIFA World Cup Group H|Group H]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jun/13/colombia-world-cup-2018-team-guide-tactics-key-players-and-expert-predictions|title=Colombia World Cup 2018 team guide: tactics, key players and expert predictions|last=Manrique|first=Camilo|date=2018-06-13|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-07-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite 3–0 and later beat Senegal 1–0 to qualify as group winners.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/jun/19/colombia-v-japan-world-cup-2018-live-updates|title=Colombia 1-2 place in FIFA soccer ranking|date=2013-07-04|work=Colombia News {{!}} Colombia Reports|access-date=2018-07-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Handball==
===France (2006–present)=== {{expand section|date=August 2018}} '''Smith & Williamson (2016-present)'''
Key players during this period include Richard Owen, of the Alton College Handy Hedgehogs.
==Ice hockey== ===Canada (2005–2016)=== Born in the mid-1980s, the [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Canadian national men's hockey team]] has had a golden generation which contributed to five consecutive [[IIHF World U20 Championship]]s between 2005 and 2009, and subsequently won back-to-back gold medals at the [[Ice hockey at the 2010 Winter Olympics - Men's tournament|2010]] and [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics - Men's tournament|2014 Winter Olympics]], and gold at the [[2016 World Cup of Hockey]].<ref>{{cite news|title= Team Canada’s golden generation not going anywhere |work= [[The Globe and Mail]]|date=February 24, 2014|url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/hockey/globe-on-hockey/team-canadas-golden-generation-not-going-anywhere/article17062885/|accessdate= April 12, 2014|first= James|last= Mirtle}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Golden generation leads Canadian men to Olympic hockey gold, again, in Sochi|work= [[National Post]]|date=February 23, 2014|url= http://sports.nationalpost.com/2014/02/23/canada-vs-sweden-sochi-olympics-mens-hockey-gold-medal-game-live/|accessdate= April 12, 2014 |first= Bruce|last= Arthur}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= No doubting Canada's dominance |work= [[ESPN]]|date=February 23, 2014|url= http://espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2014/icehockey/story/_/id/10505881/2014-sochi-olympics-canada-defense-first-mindset-delivers-win-ages|accessdate= April 12, 2014|first= Pierre|last= LeBrun}}</ref> Eleven players have also won the [[Stanley Cup]] and four are members of the [[Triple Gold Club]].
===Finland (2014–)=== Born in the mid to late 1990s, the [[Finland men's national ice hockey team|Finnish national men's hockey team]] has had a golden generation of young stars. Finland won the [[IIHF World U20 Championships]] in 2014 and 2016. In the [[2016 NHL Draft]], three of the top five picks were Finnish. <ref>{{cite news|title= How Finland has emerged as a hockey superpower |work= [[habseyesontheprize.com]]|date=June 26, 2016|url= https://www.habseyesontheprize.com/2016/6/26/11916236/finland-finnish-hockey-prospect-player-development-draft-patrik-laine-jesse-puljujarvi-olli-juolevi|accessdate= October 8, 2016|first= Patrik|last= Bexell}}</ref>
===Sweden (1991–2006)=== Born in the early 1970s, the [[Sweden men's national ice hockey team|Swedish national ice hockey team]] had a golden generation of players that achieved great success in the [[NHL]] and eventually won gold at the [[2006 Winter Olympics]], beating [[Finland]] with 3–2 in the gold medal game.<ref>{{cite news|title= Henrik Lundqvist leads Sweden into World Cup of Hockey semifinal |work= The Star|date=September 24, 2016|url= https://www.thestar.com/sports/hockey/world-cup/2016/09/24/henrik-lundqvist-leads-sweden-into-world-cup-of-hockey.html|accessdate= July 21, 2018|first= Stephen|last= Whyno}}</ref>
==Rugby union==
===Ireland (2001–2014)=== Since 2001, Ireland's team has been chosen from a solid base of players, led by [[Brian O'Driscoll]] whose debut in 1999 has been linked to a transformation in the team's fortunes.<ref name="Sunday Independent-1944005">{{cite news |url= http://www.independent.ie/sport/other-sports/rugbys-golden-children-exploded-with-the-boom-1944005.html|title= Rugby's golden children exploded with the boom|accessdate= |work= |publisher= Sunday Independent |date= November 15, 2009}}</ref> Under-21 Triple Crown victories in 1996 and 1998 and an under-19 World Cup win in 1998 occurred with many members of those teams going on to become the golden generation of the 2000s.<ref name="Sunday Independent-1944005"/> The senior team had only once in the 1990s won two [[Five Nations Championship]] games in one year (1995).<ref name="Sunday Independent-1944005"/> However, the team of the 2000s were close runners-up in the expanded [[Six Nations Championship]] several times, and were disappointingly knocked out of the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]], failing to advance from the pool stage.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://sport.guardian.co.uk/rugbyworldcup2007/story/0,,2179651,00.html | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Ireland's dying light stings Reddan in hunt for late revival | date=September 28, 2007 | first=Mike | last=Averis}}</ref> Four Triple Crowns during the 2000s equaled the amount Ireland had won in the previous one hundred years.<ref name="Sunday Independent-1944005"/> A two-win Six Nations campaign in 2008 was the exception, leading to the departure of manager [[Eddie O'Sullivan]].<ref name="Sunday Independent-1944005"/>
Their crowning moment came under [[Declan Kidney]] in 2009 when they won the Grand Slam and [[2009 Six Nations Championship|Six Nations Championship]]. They remained unbeaten throughout 2009, beating [[2007 Rugby World Cup|World]] and [[2009 Tri Nations Series|Tri Nations]] champions [[South Africa national rugby union team|South Africa]] in their final match of the year. The ''[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]'' proclaimed the 2000s as "the greatest decade in the history of Irish rugby. In the space of 10 years we have progressed from penury to riches".<ref name="Sunday Independent-1944005"/> Most of this group of players have also led their respective Irish club/provincial sides to unprecedented success, with Munster winning the [[Pro14|Celtic League]] in [[2002–03 Celtic League|2003]], [[2008–09 Celtic League|2009]] and [[2010–11 Celtic League|2011]] and the [[Heineken Cup]] in [[2005–06 Heineken Cup|2006]] and [[2007–08 Heineken Cup|2008]]; and Leinster winning the Celtic League in [[2001–02 Celtic League|2002]], [[2007–08 Celtic League|2008]], [[2012–13 Pro12|2013]] and [[2013–14 Pro12|2014]] (as well as finishing runner up in 2010, 2011 and 2012), the [[Amlin Challenge Cup]] in [[2012-13 European Challenge Cup|2013]] and the Heineken Cup in [[2008–09 Heineken Cup|2009]], [[2010–11 Heineken Cup|2011]] and [[2011-12 Heineken Cup|2012]].

[[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[High vowel|High]] | {{IPA|ɪ ɪː}} | {{IPA|ʊ ʊː}} |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | {{IPA|ɛ ɛː}} | {{IPA|ɔ ɔː}} |- ! [[Low vowel|Low]] | | {{IPA|ɑ ɑː}} |} [[Diphthong]]s that occur are {{IPA|/ɑi ɑu ɔi ui/}}. The consonants {{IPA|/l n/}} can also be [[syllabic consonant|syllabic]]. ===Consonant=== {| class="wikitable" style=text-align:center |-style="font-size: 90%;" !colspan=2 rowspan=2| !colspan=2| [[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] !colspan=2| [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] !rowspan=2| [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] !colspan=2| [[Velar consonant|Velar]] |- ! plain ! [[Labialization|lab.]] ! plain ! [[Lateral consonant|Late.]] ! plain ! lab. |- !colspan=2| [[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | {{IPAlink|m}} | | {{IPAlink|n}} | | | | |- ! [[Stop consonant|Stop]] ! [[Voicelessness|voiceless]]
/[[Voice (phonetics)|voiced]] | {{IPAlink|p}}
{{IPAlink|b}} |
(bʷ) | {{IPAlink|t}}
{{IPAlink|d}} | | | {{IPAlink|k}}
{{IPAlink|ɡ}} |
(gʷ) |- !colspan=2| [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] | | | {{IPAlink|s}}~{{IPAlink|ʃ}} |rowspan=2| {{IPAlink|ɬ}}~
{{IPAlink|l}} | | | |- !colspan=2| [[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | | | {{IPAlink|j}} | | {{IPAlink|w}} |- !colspan=2| [[Trill consonant|Trill]] | | | {{IPAlink|r}} | | | | |} {{IPA|/bʷ ɡʷ/}} are treated as single consonants by Bunn & Bunn (1970)*{{cite journal | last1 = Bunn | first1 = Gordon | last2 = Bunn | first2 = Ruth | year = 1970 | title = Golin phonology | journal = Pacific Linguistics A | volume = 23 | pages = 1–7}} , but as combinations of {{IPA|/b/}} + {{IPA|/w/}}, {{IPA|/ɡ/}} + {{IPA|/w/}} by Evans et al. (2005){{cite book | last1 = Evans | first1 = Nicholas | last2 = Besold | first2 = Jutta | last3 = Stoakes | first3 = Hywel | last4 = Lee | first4 = Alan | title = Materials on Golin: Grammar, texts and dictionary | url = http://eprints.unimelb.edu.au/archive/00001021/ | year = 2005 | publisher = The Dept. Linguistics and Applied Linguistics, The University of Melbourne | location = Parkville}}. Two consonants appear to allow [[free variation]] in their realisations: {{IPA|[s]}} varies with {{IPA|[ʃ]}}, and {{IPA|[l]}} with {{IPA|[ɬ]}}. {{IPA|/n/}} [[Assimilation (linguistics)|assimilates]] to {{IPA|[ŋ]}} before {{IPA|/k/}} and {{IPA|/ɡ/}}. ===Tone=== Golin is a [[tonal language]], distinguishing high ([˧˥]), mid ([˨˧]), and low ([˨˩]) tone. The high tone is marked by an acute accent and the low tone by a grave accent, while the mid tone is left unmarked. Examples: * High: mú [mu˧˥] 'type of snake'; wí [wi˧˥] 'scream (man)' * Mid: mu [mu˨˧] 'type of bamboo'; wi [wi˨˧] 'coming from the same ethnic group' * Low: mù [mu˨˩] 'sound of river'; wì [wi˨˩] 'cut (verb)' ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite journal |last=Bunn |first=Gordon |year=1974 |title=Golin grammar |journal=Working Papers in New Guinea Linguistics |volume=5}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Golin Language}} {{Languages of Papua New Guinea}} {{Chimbu–Wahgi languages}} [[Category:Chimbu–Wahgi languages]] [[Category:Languages of Simbu Province]] [[Category:Tonal languages]] [[Category:Subject–object–verb languages]] {{papuan-lang-stub}}

revision.text:
{{redirect|Interactive entertainment|related topics|Audience participation|and|Interactive art}} {{refimprove|date=July 2009}} [[File:Sunrise - A Song of Two Humans (DVD menu).jpg|thumb|A [[DVD-Video]] typically includes an interactive menu allowing the user to change settings or play additional content.]] '''Interactive media''' normally refers to products and services on digital computer-based systems which respond to the user's actions by presenting content such as [[text (literary theory) | text]], [[moving image]], [[animation]], [[video]], [[Digital audio | audio]], and [[video games]].
==Definition== [[Interactivity|Interactive]] media is a method of communication in which the output from the media comes from the input of the users.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interactive media|url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/i/interactive-media.asp|website=Investopedia|accessdate=3 December 2014}}</ref><ref>"When Smart Devices Interact With Pervasive Screens: A Survey", P.C. Ng, K.E. Eun, J. She, M. Baldauf, ACM Transactions on Multimedia Computing, Communications, and Applications (TOMM) Volume 13, Issue 4, August 2017. [http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3115933]</ref> Interactive media works with the user's participation. The media still has the same purpose but the user's input adds interaction and brings interesting features to the system for better enjoyment.
==Development== The analogue videodisc developed by NV [[Philips]] was the pioneering technology for interactive media. Additionally, there are several elements that encouraged the development of interactive media including the following: * The laser disc technology was first invented in 1958. It enabled the user to access high-quality analogue images on the computer screen. This increased the ability of interactive video systems. * The concept of the [[graphical user interface]] (GUI), which was developed in the 1970s, popularized by [[Apple Computer, Inc.]] was essentially about visual metaphors, intuitive feel and sharing information on the virtual desktop. Additional power was the only thing needed to move into multimedia. * The sharp fall in hardware costs and the unprecedented rise in the computer speed and memory transformed the personal computer into an affordable machine capable of combining audio and color video in advanced ways. * Another element is the release of [[Windows 3.0]] in 1990 by [[Microsoft]] into the mainstream IBM clone world. It accelerated the acceptance of GUI as the standard mechanism for communicating with small computer systems. * The development by NV [[Philips]] of optical digital technologies built around the compact disk (CD) in 1979 is also another leading element in the interactive media development as it raised the issue of developing interactive media.<ref>Lat chem, C., Williamson, J., & Henderson-Lancet, L. (1993). Interactive multimedia practice and promise. London; Philadelphia: Koran page.</ref> All of the prior elements contributed in the development of the main hardware and software systems used in interactive media.
==Terminology== Though the word ''media'' is plural, the term is often used as a singular noun.
Interactive media is related to the concepts [[interaction design]], [[new media]], [[interactivity]], [[human computer interaction]], [[cyberculture]], [[digital culture]], [[interactive design]], and includes [[augmented reality]].
An essential feature of interactivity is that it is mutual: user and machine each take an active role (see [[interaction]]). Most [[interactive computing]] systems are for some human purpose and interact with humans in human contexts.<ref name="Dix">{{Cite book | last1 = Dix | first1 = Alan | last2 = Finlay | first2 = Janet | last3 = Abowd | first3 = Gregory D. | last4 = Beale | first4 = Russell | authorlink = Alan Dix | title = Human-computer interaction. 3rd edn. | publisher = Pearson Education | year = 2004 | page = xvi | isbn = 9780130461094}}</ref> Manovich complains that 'In relation to computer-based media, the concept of interactivity is a tautology. .... Therefore, to call computer media “interactive” is meaningless – it simply means stating the most basic fact about computers.'.<ref name="Manovich">{{Cite book | last = Manovich | first = Lev | authorlink = Lev Manovich | title = The Language of New Media | publisher = MIT Press | location = Cambridge | year = 2001 | page = 55}}</ref> Nevertheless, the term is useful to denote an identifiable body of practices and technologies.
Interactive media are an instance of a computational method influenced by the sciences of cybernetics, [[autopoiesis]] and system theories, and challenging notions of reason and cognition, perception and memory, emotions and affection.
Any form of interface between the [[end user]]/[[audience]] and the medium may be considered interactive. Interactive media is not limited to [[electronic media]] or digital media. [[Board game]]s, [[pop-up book]]s, [[gamebook]]s, [[flip book]]s and [[constellation wheel]]s are all examples of printer interactive media. Books with a simple [[table of contents]] or [[Index (publishing)|index]] may be considered interactive due to the [[non-linear]] control mechanism in the medium, but are usually considered non-interactive since the majority of the [[user experience]] is non-interactive reading.<ref>[[Media psychology]] is the newest emerging dimension of media theory applied to interactive media. {{cite web |url=http://www.calstatela.edu/faculty/sfischo/MEDIADEF-2.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011010440/http://www.calstatela.edu/faculty/sfischo/MEDIADEF-2.html |archivedate=2011-10-11 |df= }}</ref>
==Advantages==
===Effects on learning=== Interactive media is helpful in the four development dimensions in which young children learn: social and emotional, language development, cognitive and general knowledge, and approaches toward learning. Using computers and educational computer software in a learning environment helps children increase communication skills and their attitudes about learning. Children who use educational computer software are often found using more complex speech patterns and higher levels of verbal communication. A study found that basic interactive books that simply read a story aloud and highlighted words and phrases as they were spoken were beneficial for children with lower reading abilities. Children have different styles of learning, and interactive media helps children with visual, verbal, auditory, and tactile learning styles.<ref>Glaucoma, Christina R., M.A. The Effects of Interactive Media on Preschoolers' Learning: A Review of the Research and Recommendations for the Future. P. 13-17. Ed. Eileen Espresso, Patti Miller, and Christine Cordoba.</ref>
===Intuitive understanding=== Interactive media makes technology more intuitive to use. Interactive products such as smartphones, iPad's/iPod's, interactive whiteboards and websites are all easy to use. The easy usage of these products encourages consumers to experiment with their products rather than reading instruction manuals.<ref>Robinson, Stuart. "The Disadvantages and Advantages of Interactive Media." EHow. Demand Media, 10 May 2011. Web. 23 Nov. 2014.</ref>
===Relationships=== Interactive media promotes dialogic communication. This form of communication allows senders and receivers to build long term trust and cooperation. This plays a critical role in building relationships. Organizations also use interactive media to go further than basic marketing and develop more positive behavioral relationships.<ref>DeYeso, Jennifer. "The Effect of Interactive and Traditional Media on Relationship Building." Slideshare. LinkedIn Corporation, 25 Apr. 2012. Web. 23 Nov. 2014.</ref>
==Influence on families== The introduction of interactive media has greatly affected the lives and inner workings of families, with many family activities having integrated with technology quite seamlessly, allowing both children and parents to adapt to it as they see fit. However, parents have also become increasingly worried about the impact that it will have on their family lives. This is not necessarily because they are opposed to technology, but because they fear that it will lessen the time that they get to spend with their children. Studies have shown that although interactive media is able to connect families together when they are unable to physically, the dependence on this media also continues to persist even when there are opportunities for family time, which often leads the adults to believe that it distracts children more than it benefits them.<ref>Taylor, Katie Headrick; Takeuchi, Lori; Stevens, Reed. "Mapping the daily media round: novel methods for understanding families' mobile technology use." Learning, Media, and Technology. 21 Oct. 2017. Accessed 4 Feb. 2018.</ref>
==Types== ===Distributed interactive media=== The media which allows several geographically remote users to interact synchronously with the media application/system is known as Distributed Interactive Media. Some common examples of this type of Media include Online Gaming, Distributed Virtual Environment, Whiteboards which are used for interactive conferences and many more.<ref>Mauve, Martin; Vogel, Jiirgen (2001) "Consistency Control for Distributed Interactive Media" Sept. 30-Oct. 5, 2001, Ottawa, Canada 123.</ref>
==Examples== A couple of basic examples of [https://www.interactivemedia.az/en/ interactive media] (also known as a company in Azerbaijan) are video games and websites. Websites, especially social networking websites provide the interactive use of text and graphics to its users, who interact with each other in various ways such as chatting, playing online games, sharing posts that may include their thoughts and/or pictures and so forth. Video games are also one of the common examples of Interactive Media as the players make use of the joystick/controller to interactively respond to the actions and changes taking place on the game screen generated by the game application, which in turn reacts to the response of the players through the joystick/controller.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/i/interactive-media.asp|title=Interactive Media|first=Investopedia|last=Staff|date=28 September 2010|publisher=}}</ref>
==Technologies and implementation== Interactive media can be implemented using a variety of platforms and applications that use technology. Some examples include mobile platforms such as touch screen smartphones and tablets, as well as other interactive mediums that are created exclusively to solve a unique problem or set of problems. Interactive media is not limited to a professional environment, it can be used for any technology that responds to user actions. This can include the use of [[JavaScript]] and [[AJAX]] in web pages, but can also be used in programming languages or technology that has similar functionality.
One of the most recent innovations to use interactivity that solves a problem that individuals have on a daily basis is [[Delta Airlines]]'s "Photon Shower".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://travel.cnn.com/delta-teases-us-shower-beats-jet-lag-473471/|title=Delta teases us with 'shower' that beats jet lag - CNN Travel|publisher=}}</ref> This device was developed as a collaboration between Delta Airlines and Professor [[Russell Foster]] of [[Cambridge University]]. The device is designed to reduce the effect of [[Jet lag|jet lag]] on customers that often take long flights across time zones. The interactivity is evident because of how it solves this problem. By observing what time zones a person has crossed and matching those to the basic known sleep cycles of the individual, the machine is able to predict when a person's body is expecting light, and when it is expecting darkness. It then stimulates the individual with the appropriate light source variations for the time, as well as an instructional card to inform them of what times their body expects light and what times it expects darkness. Growth of interactive media continues to advance today, with the advent of more and more powerful machines the limit to what can be input and manipulated on a display in real time is become virtually non-existent.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.naeyc.org/files/naeyc/file/positions/PS_technology_WEB2.pdf | title=Technology and Interactive Media as Tools in Early Childhood Programs Serving Children from Birth through Age 8|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324042025/http://www.naeyc.org/files/naeyc/file/positions/PS_technology_WEB2.pdf|archivedate=24 March 2012|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121031121333/https://www.naeyc.org/files/naeyc/PS_technology_Examples.pdf|url=https://www.naeyc.org/files/naeyc/PS_technology_Examples.pdf|title=Selected Examples of Effective Classroom Practice Involving Technology Tools and Interactive Media|archivedate=31 October 2012|publisher=|year=2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.exacttarget.com/blog/5-interactive-media-examples-of-the-new-mad-men/|title=Marketing|website=Salesforce.com}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Artmedia]] * [[Collective intelligence]] * [[Digital art]] * [[Digital media]] * [[Immersive virtual reality]] * [[Information theory]] * [[Interactive advertising]] * [[Interactive art]] * [[Interactive cinema]] * [[Interactive movie]] * [[International Interactive Communications Society]] * [[Internet think tanks]] * [[Mass collaboration]] * [[Mass media]] * [[Media psychology]] * [[Media theory]] * [[Multimedia]] * [[New media art]] * [[Social media]] * [[User-generated content]] * [[Video game]] * [[Web documentary]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://www.dgp.toronto.edu/OTP/papers/bill.buxton/3mirrors.html Bill Buxton: The three mirrors of interaction]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Interactive Media}}

revision.text:
A '''lapalissade''' is an obvious truth—i.e. a [[truism]] or [[Tautology (logic)|tautology]]—which produces a comical effect. It is derived from the name [[Jacques de la Palice]], and the word is used in several languages.<ref name=lebouc>Georges Lebouc, ''2500 noms propres devenus communs'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=zl-IBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT389 p. 389]</ref><ref name="chabanne"/><ref>Simon Baker, ''Surrealism, History and Revolution'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=RmOr-yv5ySsC&pg=PA195 p.195] <!--Basically a redundant ref; I added it only to attest the English usage--></ref>
==Origin== La Palice's [[epitaph]] reads<ref name="chabanne">Michel Chabanne (14 June 2007), comment on [http://www.mon-expression.info/une-verite-de-la-palice Encyclopédie des Expressions: Une vérité de La Palice / Une lapalissade] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303234315/http://www.mon-expression.info/une-verite-de-la-palice |date=2009-03-03 }}. Accessed 15 April 2009.</ref><ref name=lebouc/> :''"Ci-gît le Seigneur de La Palice: s'il n'était pas mort, il ferait encore envie."'' :("Here lies the Seigneur de La Palice: If he weren't dead, he would still be envied.") These words were misread (accidentally or intentionally) as "''...il ſerait [serait] encore en vie''" ("...he would still be alive"), where the [[long s]] aids in the confusion. In the 16th century this misreading was incorporated into a popular satirical song, and in time many other variants developed, including "''... que deux jours avant sa mort / il était encore en vie''" ("... that two days before his death / he was still quite alive") and "''... et quand il était tout nu, / il n'avait point de chemise''" ("... and when he was stark naked / he didn't wear a shirt").
In the early 18th century [[Bernard de la Monnoye]] collected over 50 of these humorous "La Palice" quatrains, and published them as a burlesque [[The Song of la Palice|Song of La Palice]]. From that song came the [[French language|French]] term ''[[wikt:lapalissade|lapalissade]]'' meaning an utterly obvious truth—i.e. a [[truism]] or [[Tautology (logic)|tautology]], and it was borrowed into several other languages. Since that day, when you say something very obvious, your interlocutor answers : ''"La Palice would have said as much !"'' (in French : ''"La Palice en aurait dit autant !"'').
==Similar terms==
In [[Spanish culture]], an analog is a folkloric character {{Interlanguage link multi|Pedro Grullo|es}} (Perogrullo) with his ''[[wikt:es:perogrullada|perogrullada]]s'':<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=CJXBbIXnKKwC&pg=PA131]</ref> "Verdad de Pedro Grullo, que a la mano cerrada, la llama puño" (The truth of Pedro Grullo, when his hand is closed, he calls it a fist).<ref>A dictionary of Spanish proverbs, 1834, [https://books.google.com/books?id=gPEIAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA382 p. 382]</ref>
In English, one might reference "[[Captain Obvious]]" as having spoken a [[self-evident]] truth. Other kinds of trite expressions are "[[platitude]]" and "[[wikt:bromide|bromide]]".
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:French words and phrases]] [[Category:Humour]] [[Category:Rhetoric]]

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2018}} [[Image:Leave And Earnings Statement.jpg|thumb|500px|right|Example of an LES]] A '''Leave and Earnings Statement''', generally referred to as an LES, is a document given on a monthly basis to members of the [[United States military]] which documents their pay and leave status on a monthly basis.
Employees in the [[Civil service in the United States|civil service]] receive a similar document each pay period, called a Civilian Leave and Earnings Statement, a link to which the Defense Finance and Accounting Service emails two days prior to the scheduled pay day.
==Delivery== While paper LES documents were originally mailed or handed out in person, it is now almost always retrieved by the member from an online system called MyPay from the [[Defense Finance and Accounting Service]]. For U.S. Coast Guard personnel LES can be retrieved by the member from an online system called Direct Access that is controlled by U.S. Coast Guard Personnel Services Command.
==Sections== There are multiple sections to an LES. [[File:LES Sections.png|thumb|alt=Sections of an LES]]
===Pay=== The first section lists the monetary entitlements that month. For all members it consists of Basic Pay, and for many members it also includes [[Basic Allowance for Housing]] and [[United States Military Pay|Basic Allowance for Subsistence]]. Other kinds of pay including [[Cost of Living Allowance]], [[Overseas Housing Allowance]], incentive pay, bonus pay, or hazardous duty pay may be included.
Per diem and TDY money are usually not included in the LES.
===Deductions=== The second section describes the money that has been deducted. Common deductions include: *[[Taxation in the United States|Federal and state taxes]] *[[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] *[[Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance]] (SGLI) (if the member is a participant) *[[G. I. Bill of Rights|Montgomery GI Bill]] deduction for the first year (if the member is a participant) *The service retirement center *[[Thrift Savings Plan]] (TSP) (if the member is a participant) *Mid month pay **Most members receive their money two times per month, on the 15th of the month (known as mid month pay) and on the 1st of the following month (known as end of month pay). The mid month pay is also listed in the deductions section.
===Allotments=== Common allotments include: *Bank account **Savings **Checking **Loan payment (car, etc.) *[[TRICARE]] premiums *[[Combined Federal Campaign]] (CFC) contributions *Service relief societies (i.e.: [[Navy-Marine Corps Relief Society]], [[Air Force Aid Society]], etc.)
===End of Month Pay=== After all the pay is added, all deductions & allotments are subtracted, and loose ends from previous months are accounted for, what is left is the end of month pay, which is indicated on the far right.
===Leave=== {{Main|Leave (U.S. military)}} Military members accumulate 2.5 days of leave per month or 30 days per year. The maximum amount of leave that can accrue is 60 days (this can be more if a member was deployed within the year). The fiscal year ends on September 30, unless Congress decides to make a change.
* BF Bal - Brought forward leave balance. This is the unused leave rolled over from the last fiscal year. * Ernd - The cumulative amount of leave earned in the current fiscal year, or current term of service if the service member re-enlisted or extended since the start of the fiscal year. * Used - The cumulative amount of leave used during the current fiscal year, or term of enlistment. * Cr Bal - The current leave balance as of the end of the period covered by the LES. It is calculated by BF BAL + ERNED - USED. * ETS Bal - The projected leave available through the current Expiration Term of Service. This helps make appropriate plans if the member does not plan to re-enlist. * LV LOST - The amount of leave that has been lost, usually because of having too high a balance at the end of the fiscal year. * LV Paid - The number of days of leave for which you have been paid to date. * Use/Lose - The projected number of days of leave that will be lost if not taken on in the current fiscal year on a monthly basis. The number of days of leave in this block will decrease with any leave usage.
===TSP=== {{Main|Thrift Savings Plan}} TSP information is listed near the bottom, along with the YTD (calendar year) total tax withholdings.
==See also== * [[United States Military Pay]]
==External links==
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leave And Earnings Statement}} [[Category:United States military pay and benefits]] [[Category:Leave|Earnings Statement]] [[Category:Statements]]
